title: Latch
description: Like other pieces of building hardware, latches were part of the visual status cues of the colonial British American built environment. Earlier in the eighteenth century, latches were common. They ranged from simple to highly decorated. As time went on, however, these devices came to be seen as unrefined. Locks that elegantly hid the works of a latch became the new fashion.

title: Nails
origin2: While nails were frequently made by local blacksmiths, they were also imported from British production centers, such as Birmingham.
description: Nails were small, hand-wrought pieces of metal used to secure two or more pieces of wood or other materials together. At the beginning of the eighteenth century, even these items were relatively rare in homes. As with other types of building hardware, the more a home made use of things like nails, the wealthier the inhabitants. Nails could vary drastically in their size and shape, though they were always much longer than they were wide. Machine-made nails appeared toward the end of the eighteenth century and expanded during the beginning of the nineteenth century. These allowed for hinges, locks, and other features to be even more neatly tucked away.

title: Small Cane Hoop
origin2: Most of the clothing accessories sold in the Ramsay store would have been imported from England.
description: On Sept. 27, 1753 Mrs. Sarah Wigginton purchased a 'small cane hoop' for 4 shillings. While this description is vague and could refer possibly to a hoop for needlecraft or a hoop for children's games, it likely refers to a type of undergarment which uses cane or whalebone hoops to give fullness to a woman's skirts. These could either be sewn into a petticoat or suspended like a cage from the waist. The durability and flexibility of whalebone made it the preferred material for this purpose, but its scarcity made it more expensive. Cane was used as a more economical alternative.
author: Linda Baumgarten.
book: Eighteenth-Century Clothing at Williamsburg.

title: Women's Stays
materials: Silk moire, silk cording and ribbons, linen lining
origin2: Most of the clothing accessories sold in the Ramsay store would have been imported from England.
description: Stays are a form of undergarment which utilize stiff boning to alter the wearer's posture and body shape worn in the eighteenth century by women and young children. Eighteenth century stays molded a woman's torso into a conical shape  resulting in a thin waist tapering up to support the bosom. The level of shaping caused by the stays varied based on the fashion, function, and the class of the woman. Women dressing in the height of fashion laced their stays tightly to achieve the desired effect, but for every-day practicality and especially for working women looser less restrictive stays were also available. Several credits to women customers for stays mending in Ramsay’s accounts indicate that some form of staymaking or repairing was associated with his business.
author: Linda Baumgarten.
book: Eighteenth-Century Clothing at Williamsburg.

title: Cards

description: Card games were a common form of entertainment in the colonial world. title: Violin
description: The violin, or fiddle was the most popular instrument of early America, played by men of all backgrounds from Thomas Jefferson to plantation slaves. Violins were ideal for social gatherings and tavern music because they were small and portable. Although violin sales were limited in the Ramsay store, the related purchase of fiddle strings was more common. Many fiddle strings were made of animal intestine (from animals such as goats, sheep, and cows) wrapped in silk, silver, or copper. Preferred by many musicians for their warm, rich sound, gut strings do not react well to weather fluctuations, perhaps explaining the frequency of fiddle string purchases at Ramsay’s store.
author: Ed Crews “Tavern Music”
book: CW Journal

title: Decanter
description: Decanters in colonial British America were used for holding, displaying, and serving wine and other beverages. Decanters also functioned as filtration devices, helping to remove sediments that would be present in various alcoholic beverages. Like other luxury objects from this time, an ornate glass decanter was a sign of cultivation and high status.
author: Philippa Glanville and Sophie Lee, ed.,
book: The Art of Drinking
analytics: Eight decanters were purchased from the store. Most decanters were sold individually, although one customer purchased two. These ranged in price from ten pence to four pounds six shillings. Glass was the only material noted.

title: Fork & Knife
description: Eating with knives and forks was a custom the English imported from Italy beginning in the sixteenth century. By the end of that century in England, upper class individuals were expected to use cutlery such as knives during a meal. Cutlery was more than just a tool for eating, though. These objects were a  crucial aspect of a dinner service, itself key to social status in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.
author: Helen Clifford, "Knives, Forks and Spoons, 1600-1830," in
book: Elegant Eating: Four Hundred Years of Dining in Style,
publisher: ed. Philippa Glanville and Hilary Young (London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 2002), 60-63.
analytics: Forks and knives were typically sold together and usually by the dozen. There were 26 purchases of knives and forks in the Ramsay databases. One set was identified as birch handled and another as bone scaled, indicating that Ramsay sold knives and forks of varying materials and qualities. The prices ranged from 2 shillings per dozen to 6 shillings nine pence.

description: Mugs were vessels used for drinking beverages. They could be simply adorned or lavishly decorated. The bright green glaze of the mug pictured was a novelty made possible by avid experimentation by British potters to make thinner clay bodies and brighter more controlled decoration by the mid eighteenth century.
author: Philippa Glanville and Hilary Young, ed.,
book: Elegant Eating: Four Hundred Years of Dining in Style,
analytics: There are eight purchases of mugs in the Ramsay databases. These came in either one or two quart sizes. Only one mug was qualified as stone(ware). The prices are consistently either six or nine pence, although the difference does not correspond with the size of the mug.

title: Plates
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Earthenware plates were typically imported from Staffordshire.
description: Plates are a generally flat type of dish used for eating food. They could be simple metal or ceramic objects or highly decorated pieces of art. Dining arrangements at wealthier homes could include many different plates within the same meal, for different dishes, types of food, or parts of the service. Plates were typically made of either pewter or ceramic. Pewter was more expensive but was not likely to break in handling like a ceramic one and retained some value through melting down.
author: Philippa Glanville and Hilary Young, ed.,
book: Elegant Eating: Four Hundred Years of Dining in Style,
analytics: There were twenty-one purchases of plates from the store. description: Punch bowls, commonly ranging in size from pint to two quart, were used to serve a mix of alcohol (usually rum), lemons or limes, and juices.  These bowls could be passed from drunken mouth to hand in taverns. More polite punch drinking might occur at home.

title: Mortar and Pestle
description: The mortar and pestle were common kitchen items used for various functions. Though associated together, the mortar (bowl) and pestle (small club) could be used on their own. The mortar was used as a mixing bowl for small amount of ingredients and the pestle was used to bruise or crush things. By bruising, crushing, or grinding, the use of a mortar and pestle together would allow a cook to release flavors otherwise stuck in various foods. They were also used for breaking down and combining medicinal plants and herbs.
author: Katharine E. Harbury,
book: Colonial Virginia's Cooking Dynasty

title: Shoe Buckle
origin2: Buckles were frequently imported from Sheffield or Birmingham
description: Buckles were the most common means of fastening shoes from the mid seventeenth century through the end of the eighteenth century. While they did serve a practical function, they often served as fashion accessories worn by both men and women. By changing out buckles of different styles and levels of ornament, a single pair of shoes could be adapted to different social functions. They were fashioned from a variety of metals ranging from elaborately decorated jewel-encrusted silver to simple iron rectangles. Lower grades of metal such as steel, brass, copper, or pewter were often still cast in ornamental molds.
author: Ivor Noël Hume.
book: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.
author2: James M. Gaynor and Nancy L. Hagedorn,

title: Boots

description: Mens boots were typically made of leather and were more functional and practical than women's shoes or men's pumps. Like shoes, however, most boots sold in the Ramsay store were single channel, indicating less stitching and therefore lower quality than double channel boots.

title: Women's Best Shoes
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Shoes were produced both ready to wear and to order in the colonies, but higher quality shoes were frequently imported from London.
description: Shoes in the eighteenth century, as today, varied greatly in style, function, and material. While average women's shoes would have been made of more durable leather, upper-class women's shoes were made in silks, satins, and callamancos that while beautiful, would not withstand much rigorous activity. These were frequently fastened with lavish buckles which were also status symbols. The eighteenth century shopper did not have the luxury of a standardized sizing system, shoe measurements were imprecise. The most wealthy customer could send sketches of their feet to special order from England, but even this method was not a guarantee of fit. Purchasing ready-made and imported shoes allowed the prestige and craftsmanship of London shoemakers, but was likely not a comfortable option. A further distinction is made in the accounts between single and double channel shoes which had more stitching and were therefore of higher quality.
author: Linda Baumgarten.
book: Eighteenth-Century Clothing at Williamsburg.
author2: Giorgio Riello and Peter McNeil. “Walking the Streets of London and Paris: Shoes in the Enlightenment” in
book2: Shoes : a History from Sandals to Sneakers.

Their prices range from one shilling for a pair of mens shoes to thirty-seven shillings and nine pence for a pair of womens pumps.

title: Allspice
origin2: Europeans originally encountered allspice in the West Indies.
description: Allspice is an aromatic spice made from the ground, dried berries of the tree with the same name. It was incorporated into many different recipes, especially sweets. Recent research suggests that the use of spices such as allspice was as much about their antiseptic properties as it was about their flavor.
author: Katharine E. Harbury,
book: Colonial Virginia's Cooking Dynasty
book2: The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink
analytics: There are six purchases of allspice from William Ramsay's store. Four of these are for half a pound and two are for a pound of allspice. These ranged from eight pence to one shilling one and a half pence for half a pound.

title: Salt
description: Along with pepper, salt was the most common colonial American condiment. It was frequently used for seasoning meat dishes and pickling. Salt was also the key ingredient for preserving meat.

book: Salt: A World History

title: Cinnamon
origin2: Cinnamon originally came from South Asia.
description: As a spice, cinnamon was a common British colonial American ingredient in sauces for meat, savory pies, and cakes and other desserts. It was also used for medicinal purposes.

Dr. Walter Stewart purchased two pounds of cinnamon, perhaps as an ingredient for medical remedies. The prices for these ranged from nine pence for half an ounce to seventeen shillings for two pounds.

title: Ginger (Root)

title: Pepper
origin2: Pepper originated in India and spread to other nearby climates where it could be grown.
description: Ground black pepper was the most common of all spices. Though colonial America only began to play a role in the trade of pepper after the Revolution, it was nonetheless commonly used during the colonial period. It was frequently added to meat and fish dishes, sauces, and pickles.
author: Katharine E. Harbury,
book: Colonial Virginia's Cooking Dynasty
book2: The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink
analytics: There were six purchases of pepper from William Ramsay's store. These ranged from half a pound to two pounds. The cost ranged from ten pence for half a pound to one shilling eight pence for one pound.

title: Molasses
origin2: Molasses was imported to the colonies primarily from the West Indies.
description: Molasses is a by-product from refining sugarcane into sugar. Though not as sweet as sugar, it was frequently used in desserts such as gingerbread. Molasses is used to make rum and was also used by poor people to make a kind of beer.

analytics: There were eleven purchases of molasses from William Ramsay's store. These ranged in amount from half of a gallon to sixteen gallons. In price these ranged from two shillings four pence for one gallon to four shillings six pence for half a gallon.

title: Tea
origin2: While tea was only legally allowed to be imported from Britain, smuggling from other sources was common.

Tea was certainly a high class beverage, drunk in ritual fashion with the most elegant of equipage, but research indicates that during the eighteenth century up to two-thirds of the residents of British colonial America drank tea regularly.

Serving coffee, along with tea, chocolate, and sweets, was considered a sign of proper English class.

title: Broom
artifact: Drawing of salesman with brooms and brushes
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Brooms still hold the same function today as they did in the eighteenth century, to sweep floors. In houses with dirt floors, sweeping was the only practical way of cleaning the floor as moping with water would simply turn the floor to mud. Besoms, or brooms of birch or heather twigs lashed to a handle, were ideal for sweeping dirt floors because of the rigidity of their bristles, but softer brooms of hogs hair were better suited for wood floors.
author: Seymour, John.
book: Forgotten Household Crafts.

collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Brushes were used in various types of household chores. Within the house, clothes brushes were used to remove lint and so forth from clothing, hearth brushes were used to clean ashes from the fire, and various scrub brushes were used for general cleaning. In the stables, curry brushes were used to groom horses.
author: Seymour, John.
book: Forgotten Household Crafts.

title: Brass Candlesticks
origin2: Local silversmiths manufactured candlesticks, however they were also imported from England.
description: In the eighteenth century, candlesticks were an essential part of daily life. As such, they vastly ranged in style and material. Elegant candlesticks of gold or silver served as ostentatious displays of wealth. The styles set in these were also copied in less expensive materials such as pewter and brass. Occasionally ceramic workshops emulated the styles of metal prototypes with varying degrees of success, while others focused on function. The most practical and modest consisted of squat candlesticks on a wide base with a loop for carrying made of coarse earthenware.
author: Ivor Noël Hume.
book: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.

description: Irons are used to press wrinkles out of clothing through the application of heat. The simplest form of iron used in the eighteenth century was the flat iron, which were made of solid iron and heated on the stove. Box irons took the same shape as a flat iron with a compartment that iron heaters were inserted into. Charcoal irons were similar to box irons but used burning charcoal rather than iron heaters.
author: Seymour, John.

title: Looking Glass
description: Looking glasses were mirrors used to view oneself, as decoration, or to increase the light in a room by reflection. Looking glasses came in a variety of sizes and types from small hand-held objects to view just your face and hair to large wall-mounted mirrors that were fixed in a room and could reflect more of ones surroundings. Large wall mirrors were a prestige item because of the difficulty and cost of making large panes of high-quality glass.
author: Martin, Ann Smart.
book: Buying Into the World of Goods: Early Consumers in Backcountry Virginia.
analytics: There was only one purchase of a small looking glass for five pence in the Ramsay database. This looking glass was likely much smaller and less ornate than the example, but a comparable artifact could not be found.

title: French Carpet
origin2: Carpets would mostly have been imported in the colonial period from Turkey, France, or British production centers such as Wilton, Axminster and Kidderminster.
description: In the early eighteenth century, the term carpet was ambiguous and used to describe both table carpets (or table cloths) and floor coverings. By mid century, however, the term carpet more likely refered to an unspecified type of floor covering which could vary from printed floor cloths to knotted and tufted “Turkey” carpets. Since they were still a relatively novel object, carpets would have been a status symbol in the Colonial house, a visible representation of the owner's wealth and luxury.
author: Sophie Sarin. “The Floorcloth and Other Floor Coverings in the London Domestic Interior 1700–1800.”
book: Journal of Design History

origin2: Shot was simple to produce and was often made locally. The purchases of Bristol drop shot listed in the ledger were likely imported from Bristol, England.
description: Colonial muskets and pistols required the use of small round balls of lead, or shot, propelled by an explosion of gunpowder. While shot could be sold by merchants such as Ramsay, many colonial men created their own shot in molds.

analytics: There are twenty-eight purchases of Bibles in the Ramsay Database, including gilt, large, and plain Bibles. These range from one to four Bibles. In terms of price, these ranged from one shilling five pence for one Bible to twenty-four shillings for one large Bible.

origin2: Blank books were bound by printers in the American colonies, but they were also imported from England.
description: Blank books were, as their name implies, bound volumes of blank paper. They could serve whatever function the owner needed. description: Eighteenth-century tool sets contained various instruments for all sorts of tasks. These could be as simple as a pencil and a ruler. Other sets of instruments could include a compass for measuring angles in construction or math, scales for weighing materials, and other physical or intellectual endeavors. The set pictured is a set of drawing instruments and included a ruler, protractor, and dividers.
author: James M. Gaynor and Nancy L. Hagedorn,
book: Tools: Working Wood in Eighteenth-Century America
analytics: Two sets of mathematical instruments were purchased in the Ramsay store. Their prices range from twelve shillings six pence to four pounds two pence.

title: Ink Pot
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: English or Dutch earthenware ink pots were frequently imported, though simpler stoneware ink pots may have been manufactured locally.
description: Ink pots were necessary for various aspects of writing. They could be as simple as vessels for liquid ink or more complex devices that held liquid ink, writing utensils, and stored materials for making ink.
author: E. Jennifer Monaghan,
book: Learning to Read and Write in Colonial America
analytics: There were five purchases of ink pots from William Ramsay's store. Three of which were identified as brass. While the material of the other two was unidentified, they were likely ceramic.  These ranged in price from two pence to twelve pence.

title: Inkpowder
description: Ink was a crucial element for Colonial American writing. It could be made from various materials and could thus produce a range of colors, from black and blue to red, gray, and green. The most common type of ink used during this time was called iron gall ink. It was a mixture of galls from oak stems, an iron compound, and gum. It produced a black ink that was permanent on paper.
author: E. Jennifer Monaghan,
book: Learning to Read and Write in Colonial America
analytics: There were two purchases of ink powder from William Ramsay's store. The ink was sold by the paper, probably a small envelope. These ranged in price from five pence to twelve pence.
Notes: There is no unit of sale, it just says “1 paper inkpowder”

title: Paper
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Most paper was imported from England. American paper production did not become prevalent until the later eighteenth century.
description: Paper was used then, as it is now, for a variety of purposes including writing letters, keeping accounts and lists. Paper was most frequently sold by the quire, or  twenty-four sheets. Larger orders of paper were per ream, a total of twenty quires.
author: Norman B. Wilkinson,
book: Papermaking in America
book2: A Dictionary of English Manuscript Terminology 1450–2000.
analytics: There were thirty-nine purchases of paper listed in the Ramsay Database.  Most of these were purchased by the quire; however Allan Macrae purchased two reams of paper. Most of the paper sales were not qualified but one purchase was identified as writing paper and another as post paper. In price, paper ranged from half a pence for one quire to twelve shillings six pence for a ream.

title: Penknife
origin2: Sheffield(?)
description: Penknifes were crucial to the writing process for cutting the tip of a quill so that it can be used to write. Recent scholarship indicates that penknives were not particularly popular items until the middle of the eighteenth century in Colonial America.
author: E. Jennifer Monaghan,
book: Learning to Read and Write in Colonial America
analytics: Five penknives were purchased at William Ramsay's store. Each purchase was only for one penknife. The least expensive was  four pence, however the quality and craftsmanship of the blade varied. In the Ramsay sold Barlow's best penknife and and a Stafford penknife for one pound ten shillings.
Notes: Look up manufactories of Barlow's best and Sheffield pen knives

title: Pencil
description: Though many wrote with a quill and ink during the eighteenth century, pencils were also common devices. These were basically pieces of graphite encased in wood or other materials that could be pressed onto paper to leave a mark. Eighteenth-century advertisements indicate that there were black lead, slate, and red pencils, including some made of cedar. Other types of pencils featured these materials encased in brass or other metals.
author: E. Jennifer Monaghan,
book: Learning to Read and Write in Colonial America
analytics: There were eight purchases of pencils from William Ramsay's store, including slate and steel. Customers bought anywhere from one to a dozen pencils at a time. Most purchases were for one or two pencils. These ranged in price from four pence for two pencils to eight pence for one.

title: Sealing Wax
artifact: Sealing wax and seal on envelope
description: Wax was the most common way of sealing an envelope in early eighteenth century British Colonial America. However, the messiness of the process led to other innovations. Sticky discs called wafers soon became a common method to seal an envelope, in addition to wax.
author: E. Jennifer Monaghan,
book: Learning to Read and Write in Colonial America
analytics: There are three entries in the Ramsay Database for purchases of sealing wax. Customers purchased either one or two sticks of wax. These ranged in price from thirteen pence for two sticks to eighteen pence for one stick.

title: Royal Primmer (Primer)
origin2: In the mid eighteenth century primers would have been imported from England. The New England Primer, the first primer printed in the colonies, was not published until the end of the century.
description: Primers were basic level educational books that contained topics such as the alphabet, syllables, and basic grammar lessons. They taught basic reading skills through sample sentences and standard prayers.
author: Daniel Hahn. "Books of instruction." In
book: The Oxford Companion to Children’s Literature.
analytics: There are 6 purchases of primers in the databases; 4 of these are unspecified primers and 2 are Royal Primers. The prices range from 3d to 4s.

title: Onion
origin2: Produce would have been locally grown
description: Onions came to Colonial America from England, as well as Spain, Portugal, and Italy. Even though they had a powerful smell, the bulbs resist decay and they add flavor to dishes. They frequently accompanied meat dishes.
author: Katharine E. Harbury,
book: Colonial Virginia's Cooking Dynasty
book2: The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink
analytics: Ramsay occasionally took payment in goods rather than currency. Onions appear once in the Ramsay databases as a payment to Ramsay of 1 pound and 2 shillings, and was not just a purchase of onions; it also included potatoes and peas.

title: Peas
origin2: Produce would have been locally grown
description: Peas were used in both upper and lower class dishes in England.  European explorers brought both sweet peas and field peas to Colonial America. These were used in soups, porridges, and puddings.
author: Katharine E. Harbury,
book: Colonial Virginia's Cooking Dynasty
book2: The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink
analytics: Ramsay occasionally took payment in goods rather than currency. Peas appear twice in the Ramsay databases as a payment to Ramsay. These ranged in price from 1 shilling 2 pence to 13 shillings 6 pence.

title: Venison Ham
description: Though pork was a popular meat in Colonial America, it was usually only eaten fresh seasonally. The rest of the time, people consumed cured pork products such as ham. Ham is the cured rear legs of a pig. Ham was usually produced with a dry curing process, by applying salt, saltpeter, and sugar and then smoking the meat.
author: Katharine E. Harbury,
book: Colonial Virginia's Cooking Dynasty
book2: The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink
analytics: Two people purchased ham from William Ramsay. Both purchases were for 12 shillings and 6 pence.

title: Men's Scarlet Cloak
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Most of the ready to wear clothing sold in the Ramsay store would have been imported from England. Textiles were one of the largest departments of the store, indicating that most customers made their own clothing.
description: Cloaks are loose garments worn by men, women, and children as outerwear. Men's cloaks were typically made of wool and fulled for warmth and water resistance. These goals were aided by the addition of capes to the shoulders.
author: Linda Baumgarten.
book: Eighteenth-Century Clothing at Williamsburg.
analytics: There are 14 cloaks in the Ramsay databases, of these 11 are labeled as scarlet, the other 3 are labeled as drab. Only one of these cloaks is labeled as women's and none are labeled as men's or children's. The prices range from 10s 6d to 13s 6d.

title: Women's Scarlet Cloak
dimensions: L: 41" collar to hem; Hood H: 10 1/4"; Hood Dia: 9 1/2"
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Most of the ready to wear clothing sold in the Ramsay store would have been imported from England. Textiles were one of the largest departments of the store, indicating that most customers made their own clothing.
description: Cloaks are loose garments worn by men, women, and children as outerwear. Winter cloaks were typically made of wool for warmth, but cloaks were also made in various weights and qualities of materials depending on the season and function. Red wool cloaks were the most popular style of winter wear for women.
author: Linda Baumgarten.
book: Eighteenth-Century Clothing at Williamsburg.
analytics: There are 14 cloaks in the databases. Only one cloak is labeled as women's, no gender qualifier is used for the other 13 entries. 11 cloaks are identified as scarlet, the other 3 as drab. The prices range from 9s to 13 pounds 6s.

title: Women's Mitts
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Mitts are similar in form to gloves, but with open fingers and thumbs. This allowed women to cover their hands and arms while leaving greater dexterity for sewing or other domestic labor.
author: Linda Baumgarten.
book: What Clothes Reveal: The Language of Clothing in Colonial and Federal America
publisher: (New Haven: Colonial Williamsburg Foundation in association with Yale University Press, 2002), 117.
analytics: There are 10 pairs of mitts in the databases. These were primarily purchased both by and for women. The prices range from 1.25d to 18d. Their qualifiers include fine, glazed, and coloured.

title: Silk Cap
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
analytics: There are six purchases of caps in the Ramsay databases. Of these, five are silk and one is velvet. Their prices range from four shillings two pence for a silk cap to sixteen shillings six pence for a velvet cap.

title: Gloves
analytics: There are 29 pairs of gloves in the Ramsay database with prices ranging from 10 pence for womens washing gloves to 6 shillings for buckskin gloves.

title: Men's Fine Hat
analytics: There are 50 hats for men, women, and boys in the databases. When noted, the materials are most often felt, although 2 furred hats were sold as well. The prices range from 11d for a felt hat to 22s for a man's fine hat.

title: Women's Hood
analytics: There are only 2 purchases of hoods in the Ramsay Databases. A gauze hood for 5s 6d and a velvet hood for 9s.

title: Women's Felt Hat
materials: Felted fur or wool; silk lining
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
analytics: There were fifty-eight purchases of hats in the Ramsay databases. They came in mens, womens, and boys styles. Their materials were primarily felt and furred. Other qualifiers include Hats No. 1-11, and fine. The prices ranged from 8 1/2d for a boy's hat No. 1 to 1 pound 1s 6d for a women's furred hat, band, and strings.

title: Baby Doll
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Most dolls would have either been imported from England or produced in the colonies; however as fashion models, some dolls may have been imported from Paris as well.
description: Dolls in the eighteenth century were primarily playthings, yet they also served as prescriptive devices to teach young girls. Though varying levels of sophistication and detail survive, dolls were equipped with the full range of clothing a person dressed in the same fashion would require including items such as stays, petticoats, and shoes. Dolls purchased with clothing often displayed the height of fashion and indeed may have begun life as scale models of new fashions. Dolls purchased without clothing may have served as a canvas for the girl to display her sewing abilities by constructing miniature clothing for the doll.
author: Leslie Reinhardt, "Serious Daughters: Dolls, Dress, and Female Virtue in the Eighteenth Century,"
book: American Art
analytics: There are 6 purchases of babies in the Ramsay databases which we interpret as baby dolls. Two of these dolls are identified as having glass eyes indicating a higher quality of doll than those with eyes merely painted on. The prices range from 10d each for two babies to 1 pound 8s for a baby with glass eyes.

title: Pipe
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: While, some pipes were produced locally in Virginia and New England, large quantities of pipes were imported from English, Irish, Dutch, and French manufacturers.
description: The Native American tradition of smoking tobacco through a pipe was enthusiastically taken up by the British and Colonials alike. The quality of pipes could vary greatly from crude coarseware to ornate and embellished. As a reasonably inexpensive and well used item that were frequently broken and discarded, they are ubiquitous at colonial archaeological sites to the extent that they are often frequently used to help establish dates.
author: Ivor Noël Hume.
book: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.
analytics: There were seven purchases of pipes in the Ramsay databases. Although smoking was a typically male activity, one purchase was made by a woman. They were sold by the dozen or by the gross. Although there were no qualifiers to indicate quality or type, the prices ranged from one and a half pence to sixteen pence.

title: Razor
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Razors in the American colonies were straight steel blades with handles made of bone, wood, or metal that were used to remove facial hair. By the mid eighteenth century, shaving had increasingly become a domestic activity. Technical improvements in manufacturing made reliable steel razors increasingly available to individual consumers and the use of professional barbers decreased.
author: Alun Withey. “Shaving and Masculinity in Eighteenth-Century Britain.”
book: Journal for Eighteenth-Century Studies
analytics: There were seven purchases of razors in the Ramsay databases. They were primarily sold either individually or by the case, this distinction could identify consumers purchasing razors for personal use and professional barbers. Qualifiers used to describe razors in the ledger are fine polished, razors No. 145, and rusty. The prices ranged from 4d for three rusty razors to 15s for a case of razors.

title: Snuff Box
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
analytics: There were four purchases of snuff boxes in the Ramsay databases. Although taking snuff was a male dominant activity, three of the four purchases of snuff boxes were by women. Their prices range from nine pence to two shillings.

title: Spectacles
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
analytics: There were four pairs of spectacles purchased in the Ramsay databases. Three pair sold for 6d, while the fourth sold for 4d.

title: Watch String
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
analytics: There are five watch strings in the Ramsay databases. Two are identified as watch string No. 144, one is identified as a best watch string, and the fourth is identified by size (one eighth). Their prices range from ten pence to one shilling eight pence.

title: Half Curb Bridle
collection: Diderot et d'Alembert via Wikimedia Commons
book2: Recueil de Planches, sur Les Sciences, Les Arts Libéraux, et Les Arts Méchaniques, avec Leur Explication.
analytics: There are eight purchases of bridles in the Ramsay databases. Four of these are for half curb bridles, two for snaffle bridles, and two for best small bridles. Their prices range from two shillings six pence for a snaffle bridle to four shillings six pence for a half curb bridle.

title: Spring Spurs
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
analytics: There are only three purchases of spurs in the Ramsay databases. All three are identified as spring spurs, and two are identified as steel. Their prices range from one shilling nine pence to three shillings.

title: Fine Silvered Coat Buttons
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: While there were a few known button manufacturers in colonial  America, buttons for the most part would have been imported from England or elsewhere in Europe.
description: As buttons were used to fasten a wide array of clothing, they are ubiquitously found in colonial archaeological sites. Buttons came in a wide variety of styles and types. Many buttons, particularly for women's dresses, would have been covered in fabric. Metal or metal plated buttons were popular particularly for coats and could be highly ornate. Buttons could be fastened directly via holes through the button or through eyes attached to the back of the button.
author: Ivor Noël Hume.
book: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.
analytics: There were sixty-six purchases of buttons in the Ramsay databases. They came in an assortment of types including coat, shirt, sleeve, and breast. Their materials include silver, silvered, gold, gilt, and mettle. Other qualifiers included fine, best, black, and scarlet. They were usually sold by the dozen, but occasionally by the pair. Their prices ranged from 2d for 1/2 dozen breast buttons to 7 pounds for a dozen scarlet breast buttons.

title: Thimble
description: Humble and utilitarian or ornamental and personalized, thimbles are tools used to protect the fingers from developing calluses when hand stitching. Though the basic design of colonial thimbles did not vary greatly, the size and weight of a thimble was dependent on the size of the user's hands and the type of stitching.  Intimate gift, valuable possession, or aesthetic pleasure, thimbles were often engraved with initials and were one of few commodities a woman might literally call her own.
author: Ivor Noël Hume.
book: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.
analytics: There are 29 thimbles in the Ramsay databases. Surprisingly 23 of the thimble sales were to men. This may reflect the various types of sewing which could require a thimble including tailors, shoemakers, and sailors in addition to dressmakers and domestic sewing. Most purchases were for 1 or 2 thimbles, but Henry Vanmetre purchased a dozen thimbles on December 6, 1753.

title: Pair of Knitting Needles
origin2: Knitting needles could be made locally either by whittling them from wood, or produced by colonial blacksmiths; however metal needles were frequently imported from England.
description: Knitting needles were used to produce garments out of yarn which was frequently spun at home. Hand knitting was one aspect of the women's contribution to domestic economy and was a desired skill both as a marketable skill for servants and slaves and as an accomplishment for the women of the family. Socks made up the majority of functional knitwear in the American colonies, but items such as mittens and shawls were frequently produced as well.
author: Adrienne D. Hood
book: The Weaver's Craft: Cloth, Commerce, and Industry in Early Pennsylvania.
analytics: There are eight purchases of knitting needles in the Ramsay databases sold in pairs. Although there are no qualifiers, their prices range from two pence to eighteen pence.

title: Needles
collection: Thérèse de Dillmont via Wikimedia Commons
description: Needles were a ubiquitous part of colonial life. As evidenced by the large quantities of textiles, needles, and pins sold in the Ramsay store, most of its customers made their own clothing at home. Since sewing was broadly considered “women's work” and when considered in light of embroidery, the needle was the woman's pen with which she asserted her agency on the world. However, the sale of several sail needles remind us that this tool had varied uses and was also wielded by men as well.
author: Goggin, Maureen Daly, and Beth Fowkes Tobin.
book: Women and the material culture of needlework and textiles, 1750-1950.
book2: Encyclopedia of Needlework.
analytics: There are twenty-one purchases of needles in the Ramsay databases, nine of which are identified as sail needles. Needles were sold in quantities ranging from two to one hundred and thirty. Their prices range from one and a half pence for ten sail needles to eighteen pence for a dozen sail needles.

title: Pins
description: Pins were an integral part of hand sewing and mending. Because they were so ubiquitous, small, and easy to loose, they are frequently found in large numbers at historical sites. Many pins found at colonial sites were brass and were tin-plated.
author: Ivor Noël Hume.
book: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.
analytics: There are 16 sales of pins in the Ramsay databases. Pins were sold by the weight. Although there are no qualifiers indicating quality, the price was either 6d or 8d for 1 weight.

title: Ribbon
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Ribbons had many uses and meanings in the eighteenth century and were purchased by both women and men of varying social status. As accessories they could be used to trim a new dress, revitalize an old dress, adorn ones hair, decorate ones hat, or wear as a necklace. Practically, they were used to tie aprons, bonnets, and breeches; fasten purses and pocketbooks; or hang objects on the wall. Symbolically, men exchanged ribbons with women  as part of a courtship ritual indicating desire.
author: Ann Smart Martin. "Ribbons of Desire: Gendered Stories in the World of Goods," in
book: Gender, Taste, and Material in Britain in America in the Long Eighteenth-century,
analytics: There are seventeen purchases of ribbon in the Ramsay databases. There are multiple qualifiers including ribbon No. 1-7, lace, satin, black, and love ribbons. Twelve of the seventeen purchases were made by men. Ribbon was sold by the yard and the prices range from 6d. to 12d.

title: Fine Colored Thread
description: Thread was a ubiquitous part of colonial life. As evidenced by the large quantities of textiles, needles, and pins sold in the Ramsay store, most of its customers made their own clothing at home. Thread was sold in a variety of qualities and colors and was used primarily for sewing, mending, and embroidery.
author: Goggin, Maureen Daly, and Beth Fowkes Tobin.
book: Women and the material culture of needlework and textiles, 1750-1950.
analytics: There are one hundred and twenty two purchases of thread in the Ramsay databases. In addition to colors, thread is qualified in types such as fine, best, and nun's thread. Thread was most commonly sold by the ounce, though some larger purchases were weighed in pounds. Their prices ranged from two pence for an ounce of thread to four shillings nine pence for a half ounce of fine white and brown thread No. 18.

title: Silk Fringe
dimensions: Height: 3.5 cm, Width: 22.86 cm, Width: 9 in
analytics: There were eight purchases of fringe in the Ramsay databases. Fringe was sold in black, white, and blue. The only listed material was silk, and there were two purchase of fringe No. 2. Their prices ranged from two shillings for four and a half yards of white fringe to seventeen pence for six yards of fringe no. 2.

title: Fine Lace
analytics: There are twenty-one purchases of lace in the Ramsay databases. They were made of cotton or silk. Other qualifiers include black and fine. Their prices range from four pence for lace, to seven shillings nine pence for fine lace.

title: Small Scissors
book2: A Guide to Artifacts of Colonial America.
analytics: There are 10 pairs of scissors in the Ramsay databases. One pair is identified as small scissors but there are no other qualifiers. Their prices range from five pence to nine pence.

title: Hussar Plush
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Most of the textiles sold in the Ramsay store were either produced and imported from England, or imported to the colonies through England. Plush was produced primarily in France.
description: A wool velvet primarily used for clothing and upholstery. As clothing, it was popular for livery. Because of it's weight and warmth, it was also used for winter coats.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are only four purchases of Plush in the Ramsay databases. Three are identified as hussar plush. Their prices range from ten shillings to thirteen shillings six pence.

title: Bombazine
materials: red silk warp, brown wool weft
origin2: Bombazine was primarily produced in Spitalfields and Norwich.
description: Bombazine is a combined fabric with a silk weft and worsted weft. It was used for window dressings and clothing. It's lighter weight made it suitable for summer attire.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are only two purchases of bombazine in the Ramsay databases. There are no qualifiers, but Hugh West Jr. paid only three shillings a yard for bombazine, while Dr. Walter Stuart paid three shillings four pence per yard.

title: Broadcloth
materials: broadcloth, silver threads, bullion, and sequins
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Broadcloth is a type of sturdy wool that was both carded and fulled. It was primarily used for clothing, particularly for coats and outerwear.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are six purchases of broadcloth in the Ramsay databases. Of these, two are black and one is scarlet, two are identified as fine and a third as finest, indicating a range of qualities and colors of broadcloth. We can't always trust these qualifiers however, since the entry for finest black broadcloth is the lowest price at 18d per yard and the prices range up to 14s 6d per yard for fine broadcloth.

title: Buckram
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
description: Buckram is a stiff coarse fabric of hemp. It was primarily used to stiffen garments and accessories such as bodices, hats, or outerwear into a desired shape. Since buckram was typically sewn on the interior of garments, it could be produced new or made of re-purposed fabric.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are thirteen purchases of Buckram in the Ramsay Databases. There are no qualifiers to indicate quality or type. Buckram was usually purchased by the yard, though occasionally by the piece. The purchases are for quantities of 1 yard or smaller, likely since it was only used in areas where fabric needed to be stiffened. The prices range from 2.5d for 1/4 yard to 1s 10d for 1 piece.

title: Calico
origin2: Though advancements in textile technology allowed British and American tradesmen to produce calico after 1774, any calico sold in the 1750s would have been imported from India.
description: Calico refers to a linen-like cloth made of cotton. The name calico comes from the city Calicut in India where calico was first produced. It was used for clothing, handkerchiefs, quilts, and drapery.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are 7 sales of calico in the Ramsay databases. Many of them are not identified by qualifiers, but 3 of them are labeled as calicoes No. 1, No. 2, and No. 3 indicating that there were different types of calico for sale at the Ramsay-Dixon store. The prices range from 3s to 7s 6d.

title: Calimanco
origin2: Most of the textiles sold in the Ramsay store were either produced and imported from England, or imported to the colonies through England.
description: Calimanco was a worsted textile used for furnishing, clothing, and quilted coverlets. It was valued for its gloss and brilliance.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are 11 purchases of calimanco in the Ramsay databases. It was sold in color variations of scarlet, yellow, black, blue or green as well as flowered but there are no qualifiers to indicate the quality of fabric. The prices for calimanco range from 12d to 1s 10d per yard.

title: Cambric
origin2: Cambric was primarily produced in France and Britain.
description: Cambric is a thin linen fabric used for clothing and clothing accessories such as fichus and cravats as well as curtains. It was typically bleached and worn white rather than ornamented or dyed.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are only three purchases of cambric in the Ramsay databases.

title: Chintz
origin2: While this technique was developed in India, a modified version of this technique was being used to produce chintz in England as early as 1676; therefore chintz could have been imported from either.
description: Chintz refers to a printed cotton created with a madder-mordant technique. In colonial America, chintz was used for both clothing and upholstery.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are only 2 sales of chintz in the Ramsay databases. 6.5 yds of Chintz No. 5 sold for 32s, while 13.5 yds of Fine Chintz No. 6 sold for only 5s 3d.
Notes: The ledger does say “ 6 1/2 yds. Chintz @ 32/” but it doesn't add up to the line total which is 1,, 15,, 10 1/2. Could you look into this?

title: Crape
origin2: Most of the textiles sold in the Ramsay store were either produced and imported from England, or imported to the colonies through England.
description: Crape was a lightweight gauzy fabric made of silk, worsted, or worsted with silk. It was used primarily for clothing and head wear. Though it was made in a variety of colors, black crape was particularly popular for mourning clothes.
author: Florence M. Montgomery.
book: Textiles in America, 1650-1870 : a Dictionary Based on Original Documents : Prints and Paintings, Commercial Records, American Merchants' Papers, Shopkeepers' Advertisements, and Pattern Books with Original Swatches of Cloth.
analytics: There are only three purchases of crape in the Ramsay databases. One is identified as silk crape, another as black crape, and the third as hat band crape. Their prices range from two shillings six pence per yard for silk crape to one pound seventeen shillings and six pence for fifteen yards of black crape.

title: Dimity
collection: Image Courtesy of The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation
origin2: Most of the textiles sold in the Ramsay store were either produced and imported from England, or imported to the colonies through England.
description: Dimity is a patterned fabric woven in a harness-loom. While initially woven of cotton, some sources refer to linen and silk dimities as well. It is related to fustian; however, where fustian is woven plain and died, dimity is woven with a pattern ranging from simple stripes or checks to more elaborate floral motifs. It was used primarily for clothing and bedding.

title: Hank of Silk
origin2: Since attempts to produce silk in the American colonies met with limited success, most silk in the eighteenth century was imported from Asia through English suppliers.
description: Made from fibers found in the cocoons of silkworms, silk threads can be spun extremely fine and still remain strong. Silk thread was sold by the hank for use in embroidery, a popular means of decorating clothing, footwear, furnishings, and many other textile products. Because of its softness and luster, as well as the difficult process and limited resources, silk was a luxury commodity for colonial consumers as it remains for us today. In addition to hanks of silk thread, Ramsay also sold silk textiles of various types such as Persian, Crape, and Allamode by the yard.
author: Smith, Gideon B. “Treatise on the Culture of Silk.”
book: Southern Agriculturist and Register of Rural Affairs (1828-1839)
book2: The Weaver's Craft: Cloth, Commerce, and Industry in Early Pennsylvania.
analytics: There are 44 purchases of hanks of silk in the Ramsay Databases. The silk purchases are not identified with qualifiers indicating quality or type, though 6 are identified black silk. The prices range from 4d to 2s 6d per hank.

title: Damask
origin2: Most of the textiles sold in the Ramsay store were either produced and imported from England, or imported to the colonies through England.
description: Patterns are created in damask fabric by alternating between warp- and weft-float faces of a weave. This contrast can be between two tones of silk, or silk and another fiber. The pattern appears raised off of the background creating a textured fabric, this is particularly pronounced when the silk is woven with a thicker fiber. Damask was used for clothing, drapery, and upholstery. When used in upholstery, it was often paired with covers of a sturdier fabric for daily use in order to preserve the damask for special occasions.

title: Velvet

Velvet could be made of silk, wool, linen or cotton and the combinations of materials contributed to the density and coarseness of the material. Stout linens made of linen or wool were more likely used for upholstery whereas silk velvets were more likely intended for clothing.
